key_excerpts.excerpt: Iran's Supreme Leader holds ultimate authority over all branches of government. He has constitutional control over the judiciary, the regular military, and the elite Revolutionary Guards, as well as state media and half of the powerful Guardian Council.
The Presidency, while the highest elected office, has substantially less authority than the unelected institutions.

The Assembly of Experts is a body of ~88 Islamic jurists that is constitutionally empowered to appoint or dismiss the Supreme Leader. In practice, however, this assembly has never removed a leader and has largely acted as a rubber stamp.
The Guardian Council is a 12-member body that wields veto power over legislation and elections. Six clerics are appointed by the Supreme Leader and six jurists nominated by the judiciary.
The Expediency Discernment Council serves as a high-level advisory and arbitration body. Its original mandate was to resolve deadlocks between the parliament and the Guardian Council.

The Majles (Islamic Consultative Assembly) is Iran's 290-seat parliament. It drafts and passes legislation and can summon or impeach ministers. However, its legislative power is constrained by the Guardian Council.

The Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) is one of the most powerful institutions in Iran, created after the 1979 revolution as the principal defender of the new Islamic Republic. The IRGC answers directly to the Supreme Leader and operates parallel to the regular military.

The Basij is a paramilitary volunteer militia under IRGC command, used as the regime's grassroots enforcers. Integrated fully under IRGC control since 2007, the Basij can reportedly mobilize hundreds of thousands of loyal volunteers in times of crisis.

The Artesh - Iran's regular army - is tasked primarily with defending Iran's borders against external threats. Since the 1979 revolution, the Artesh has been kept largely apolitical and sidelined in strategic decision-making.

The Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS) is Iran's primary civilian intelligence agency. It falls under the executive branch but works closely with parallel IRGC intelligence units. Iran's intelligence network is extensive.

The IRGC has built a sprawling economic empire across Iran's economy. It controls major construction and engineering firms, owns or influences businesses in sectors ranging from energy and transport to telecoms and agriculture.
July 1999 Student Protests: Security forces stormed university dormitories at night, brutally attacking sleeping students. Several students were killed, dozens injured, and hundreds arrested.
June 2009 Green Movement: Millions of Iranians marched under the 'Where is my vote?' slogan. Dozens of protesters were killed and thousands were arrested.
December 2017 - January 2018 Protests: Unrest spread to more than 100 cities across all 31 provinces. Over 20 people killed and over a thousand arrested.

November 2019 'Bloody Aban' Protests: Security forces killed anywhere from 304 people (per Amnesty International) to possibly around 1,500 people over just a few days. Near-total internet blackout for about a week.
September 2022-2023 Mahsa Amini Uprising: Approximately 500+ protesters killed, over 20,000 detained. The regime executed at least four young demonstrators.
Egypt 2011: The Egyptian army signaled it would not resort to use of force against demonstrators. On February 11, 2011 - after 18 days of protest - the military pushed Mubarak to resign.
Iran has developed a playbook for information blackouts. When nationwide protests erupt, authorities shut down or severely throttle the internet.
The Iranian government maintains strict control over information via pervasive censorship and state media dominance. All domestic broadcasters are state-owned.

Sudan 2019: Some rank-and-file Sudanese soldiers began siding with the crowd - opening gates and even exchanging fire with regime loyalists to protect protesters. On April 11, they arrested Bashir. Time to defection: approximately 4 months.
Romania 1989: The Romanian Army defected en masse to the side of the revolution, refusing to fire on the people. Ceausescu was captured and executed. Time to defection: about one week.
US Escalation Ladder: Washington has signaled willingness to escalate pressure substantially in a severe Iran crisis, including cyber weapons, sanctions, and even limited military strikes.
Persians comprise the majority, roughly 60% of Iran's population, and form the core of the state.
Iranian Azeris are the largest minority, estimated ~16% of the population. They are relatively well integrated into the power structure.
Kurds account for roughly 10% of Iran's population. Several Kurdish armed groups persist, including KDPI, Komala, and PJAK.
Arabs of Iran comprise ~2% of the population concentrated in oil-rich Khuzestan province.
Turkmens form roughly 2% of Iran's population. They staged uprisings in 1979-1980 which were suppressed.

The Baluch are a Sunni Muslim ethnic group constituting about 2% of Iran's population. Their province is one of Iran's poorest - over 70% live under the poverty line. Militant groups Jundallah and Jaish al-Adl have waged armed resistance.

organization: Institute for the Study of War
title: Russia and China Positioning on Iran

key_excerpts.excerpt: Russia is a strategic partner of Tehran. Moscow's playbook is to provide diplomatic cover and some material support to Iran, while avoiding getting entrapped in Iran's domestic turmoil.
China maintains strong economic ties with Iran. Beijing's overriding interest is regional stability and uninterrupted energy flows. China would oppose foreign military intervention in Iran.

organization: Institute for the Study of War
title: Israel Red Lines on Iran

key_excerpts.excerpt: Israel views Iran's regime as its most dangerous adversary. Israeli leaders have repeatedly warned they will not permit Iran to acquire nuclear weapons capability.
